awd_titl_txt: IDBR:  A label-free biomolecular sensing instrument based on monolithic optical resonators and an optoelectronic swept-frequency semiconductor laser
awd_abstract_narration:
Project Abstract
This project proposes the development and demonstration of a label-free sensing instrument based on the integration of an electronically controlled linear swept-frequency semiconductor laser, a high quality factor (Q) optical resonator with covalent surface functionalization, and a microfluidic cell for analyte delivery. It will address a number of key issues that currently prevent this technology from becoming an accessible, affordable, and useful tool. These efforts will develop the optical cavity sensing platform to a point where it is robust and repeatable, and provides sensitivity and cost-effectiveness that are at least an order of magnitude better than any available alternative biomolecular assay instrument.
The proposed system will combine the results of two major recent developments in the field of optical and laser physics: the high-Q optical resonator and the phase-locked electronically controlled swept-frequency semiconductor laser. The high-Q optical resonator is part of a monolithic unit with an integrated optical waveguide, and is fabricated using standard semiconductor lithography-based methods. Optoelectronic swept frequency lasers will be developed at wavelengths relevant for aqueous sensing, and will replace expensive and fragile mechanically-tuned laser sources whose frequency sweeps have limited speed, accuracy and reliability. The resonator will be functionalized using known techniques providing an adaptable and selective surface chemistry. The sensor will include an integrated microfluidic flow cell for precise and low volume delivery of analytes to the resonator surface.
The proposed instrument represents an adaptable and cost-effective platform capable of various sensitive, label-free measurements relevant to the study of biophysics, biomolecular interactions, cell signaling, and a wide range of other life science fields. It will be capable of binding assays, thermodynamic and kinetics measurements, and has the potential for additional impact through integration into existing instruments to replace less sensitive analytical methods. The sensor also has potential applications in point-of-care medical diagnostics, where it can enable early detection of relevant antigens.
The project is inherently multidisciplinary and will develop expertise in and better understanding of the interplay between such diverse fields as semiconductor lasers, optical nanofabrication, high speed electronics, control systems, fiber-optics, microfluidics, biomolecular binding assays, mass transfer, and integrated instrument design. It affords the opportunity for two graduate students and an undergraduate student to take part in a collaborative research effort under the close guidance of the PIs, educating the students in the culture of scientific discovery, alongside engineering and application considerations. The results obtained during the course of the project will be published in leading scientific journals and conferences.

por.por_cntn:
This project focused on developing a rapid and low-noise platform employing microring resonators for detecting low concentrations of biomolecules. The platform has a wide range of applications, from analytical chemistry and biology to medical diagnostics. Using microring resonators to detect small changes in index of refraction has many advantages, including very high sensitivity and specificity. The project has made important advances on multiple fronts, including reducing the noise due to environmental temperature and pressure drifts, accelerated fluidic transport, improved chemical protocols, and rapid optical detection.

The most important innovation of this project is the fluidic delivery of the chemicals of interest to a dual, laminar flow platform (Figs.1, 2). This platform allows for the differential measurement between two resonators situated in the same channel, one exposed to the analyte solution, the other to a reference buffer. The placement of the resonators in close proximity to each other enables sensing with a differential signal that reduces effects of environmental pressure and temperature transients, thereby reducing noise and signal drift. In addition to the co-laminar flow channel, the platform employs PDMS elastomeric valves, which reduce the sensing time resulting from fluidic transport. These valves have a low fluidic dead volume, and enable switching transients between inlets of ~10s. Lastly, we have shown that certain geometries of the fluidic channel can help improve mass transport to the sensor, and studied the impact of different channel parameters through finite element simulations. 

Important steps have been taken to improve the chemical protocols used in the surface functionalization of the resonators. Having repeatable and robust protocols for depositing a single monolayer of the linker chemical between the substrate and the ligands of interest is critical in achieving a robust platform. By testing a number of deposition conditions, such as the concentration and the solvent of the linker layer, we optimized the deposition parameters of the linker layer. This layer can be employed in the study of a multitude of chemical interactions.

In terms of the optics used, the laser employed to interrogate the resonant frequencies of the microring resonators is a linearly swept optoelectronic frequency laser, with a sweep scan of 300GHz in 2ms. The laser developed in our group rapidly and repeatedly interrogates the transmission spectrum of the resonators. The precisely controlled linearity of the sweep allows for easy post-processing of the signals. This laser has applications in many other fields, including three-dimensional imaging and laser radar.

In conclusion, the project has made significant contributions in many directions related to the use of microring resonators as biosensing tools.
